newsitem.title: PORTUGAL: Portugal's Banco Espirito Santo boosts 1996 profit.
newsitem.headline: Portugal's Banco Espirito Santo boosts 1996 profit.

text.p: Portugal's third biggest private bank Banco Espirito Santo (BES), benefiting from a boost in credit and insurance business, said on Tuesday it raised its 1996 profit by 21.3 percent year-on-year to 23.593 billion escudos ($143 million).
The bank will maintain its policy of distributing at least 50 percent of its profits as dividends to shareholders, BES president Ricardo Espirito Santo Salgado said.
"The policy of distributing at least 50 percent of results is central to the bank and will continue," he told Reuters.
BES has proposed a dividend on its 1996 results of 131.6 escudos per share, up from 114.5 the previous year.
The financial margin of the bank is expected to be steady or to rise slightly in 1997, Espirito Santo Salgado said.
"It is possible to predict that margins will not continue to fall, or that they could recover slightly," he said.
The bank's financial margin eased to 2.7 percent in 1996 from 2.9 percent in 1995.
Espirito Santo Salgado said the bank expected to post a good performance in 1997 but it will be hard to maintain profit growth of around 20 percent.
"It is natural that we will continue to grow well," he said. "We believe that 1997 will also be a good year."
He added: "But to maintain profit growth of around 20 percent would be very difficult. We cannot predict such a level of profit growth."
Espirito Santo Salgado said the bank would focus on organic growth which would benefit shareholders.
The bank's total deposits rose to 2,924 billion escudos in 1996 from 2,449 billion in 1995. Total loans rose to 1,512 billion escudos in 1996 from 1,222 billion in 1995.
